content.question: A particle of mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> moves from point <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to point <math alttext="D " overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>D</mi></mstyle></math> along the path shown in the diagram. At each of the four labeled points, the net force on the particle is represented by a vector. How can one tell that the kinetic energy of the particle is increasing at point <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: The net force has the greatest magnitude at point <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The net force and velocity are nearly parallel at point <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The speed of the particle is the least at point <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The particle is moving downhill at point <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The net force is not in the direction of motion at the four other points.

content.answer: The net force and velocity are nearly parallel at point <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
